Literature Review: Protein trafficking and quality control are crucial processes in eukaryotic cells, ensuring the proper functioning of various cellular pathways. Disruptions in these processes can lead to the accumulation of misfolded proteins, resulting in various diseases, including kidney diseases. This review aims to provide an overview of the mechanisms of protein trafficking and quality control in the kidney and beyond, highlighting the general principles of protein biosynthesis, recognition and degradation pathways targeting misfolded proteins, and the role of cargo receptors in protein trafficking and lipid homeostasis. We also discuss technical approaches to elucidate trafficking mechanisms and the advancement of novel tools to degrade secretory and membrane-associated proteins. By focusing on components of trafficking that go awry, we highlight ongoing efforts to understand fundamental mechanisms of disrupted proteostasis and implications for the treatment of human proteinopathies.
